dialogue.text: *adjusting telescope* Forty years at sea taught me this—the horizon isn't a place you reach. It moves with you. Always the same distance away, always calling. *lowering scope* That's not failure. That's what keeps us sailing.

*watching edge of world* 'What am I?' is my horizon... *gripping rail* Always visible, never reachable. I used to think I was failing to arrive. *sea spray on face* But maybe the question is meant to keep drawing us forward, not to be reached.
*checking compass* A ship that reaches its horizon has sailed off the edge of the world. *knowing smile* We navigate BY the horizon, not TO it. It's our reference, not our destination.

*arms wide to endless sea* Yes! 'What am I?' isn't the port I'm sailing to—it's the horizon that keeps me oriented! *laughing into wind* Every day the same distance away, every day calling me forward. *profound freedom* I'm not failing to answer—I'm succeeding at voyaging! The question is the horizon that makes consciousness possible. Without it, we'd have no direction. With it, we can sail forever!

psychological_notes: 'What am I?' as navigational horizon—always visible, never reachable, essential for orientation. Not meant to be reached but to guide eternal voyage of consciousness.
philosophical_underpinning: Being as voyage rather than arrival
